description:
From the Bride:
 El Tonayense have been my favorite food truck well before the food truck explosion.  I think, they are one of the best Mexican food in town.  I wanted them involved in our wedding.  Our wedding was on July 7, 2018 in Oakland's Preservation Park.Our guests thought the food they served were great.  My favorite item is the lengua taco, which was very tasty and tender.  The server they had for our wedding was also very fun.  Our guests had a great time interacting with them.  

From the Groom:
 I agree.
author: Joan R.

description:
They were outside of an event at Harlot that I was attending.  I know I was drinking, but that was a damn good lengua taco!  Perfect amount of sauce and the tongue was tender!  

Next time they're around I'll probably try some other meat, but you can't blame a girl for wanting some tongue, especially when she's been drinking, right?  *Insert dirty comment here.*
author: Cat C.

description:
As taco trucks go, El Tonayense does it the best. Flavor and value are both excellent here. It probably also helps that this truck seems to follow me around the City, though in all likelihood, it just hovers on the block by Mission Cliffs to snag all the hungry climber folk.

Lengua and carnitas are awesome here! I'm so glad I followed the lead of a Mexcian family who ordered a dozen tongue meat tacos. SUCH soft meat, and it all soaks up the marinade.
author: Kevin L.

description: I had never been to a taco truck before and I was a little leary of the whole idea but my friend insisted so we tried and I'm so glad we did. El Tonayense is the name - I will tottally be going back. I wish there was more room to sit down but the whole "truck" element left us without and I ended up getting taco sauce on my new shirt =( other than that this place was amazing!
author: Marisa K.

description: I LOVE absolutely everything about El Tonayense carnitas spicy tacos!!!! (guacamole sauce extra).  Two moist tasty corn tortillas support a mound of juicy succulent meat with the most incredible smoky/spicy sauce generously drizzled on top along with some minced onion.  Several slivers of pickled jalapeño pepper and radish plus slices of lime on the plate to add even more flavors.  The guacamole sauce lends yet another layer of flavor plus reduces the heat a bit.  Better than anything from a 5-star pricy sit-down restaurant.  Delicious!  Truck parked outside Best Buy convenient when shopping at Rainbow Grocery.
author: Tree C.

description:
I came through late last night to this truck to grab a few tacos. Unlike the one that parks on 22nd and Harrison, this truck is located on a dark street corner without tables and chairs. I contemplated for a while before settling for a tripa and carnita tacos for $1.75 each. Even though it's still El Toyanese, the vibe was radically different as there was no one walking around within that three block radius. It was pitch black and all quiet but the two guys in the truck. Instead of walking away my anticipation was upheld by a red flier posted on their window to assure that they are Yelp approved. 

By the first look of my tacos, they were huge and juicy with two layers of tortillas to keep the stacks of meat and salsa intact. The hot salsa was noticeably thicker than the other truck, and the sight of these pickled jalapenos was just magnificent. I was ready to dig in. I've been ready all day. This is what greasy messy spicy foodilicious tacos were all about. As it turns out, looks and the actual taste were a world apart. Both the tripa and carnita were way over-fried to which the carnita was dry without much redeeming value while the tripa was tough and noticeably soaked in grease for too long. I thought the salsa was decent but it did not have any effect in bringing some sort of balance to these super oily tacos. Portions were generous but I literally thought I was eating lard.

There's a good chance that I might have ordered the wrong things since I didn't see other reviewers talk about their tripa. On the other hand, Tom R. did warned me about their big head syndrome from yelp exposure so I think this may be a case in point of an over hyped truck that has since raised its price while letting its quality slip to the deep end. 2 stars for the food and another half star for cleanliness. Yelp may approve the truck, but I won't recommend it.
author: Daniel L.

description:
What can you say? A Michelin recommended TACO TRUCK?!?! Are you kidding me?

The burrito I had was delicious and I would give it five stars, but I want to go back and make sure it wasn't a fluke :-P.

The location was convenient, the food was fresh and hot.  I had the chicken burrito and i heard their carne asada was even better, so i can't wait to make it back to try.

Happy Eating!
author: Bradley H.

description:
Only 3 stars???  I know.  Don't hate me because I'm dutiful.  

The thing is, El Tonayense is a 5-star choice for the taco lover... who eats meat.  But thems who don't get a taco that's really just a big scoop of raw onions and beans.  So kind of like a taco I'd imagine you'd get in jail.  

If you eat fish, there is some relief for you.  These guys do a yumaaaaazing fish taco-- but only on Fridays.

To be fair, these trucks are insanely clean, have efficient, friendly service, and serve up grilled meats that the carnivores LOVE.  The Mr. uses grand hand gestures to describe the carne asada taco.  And the salsa here is so much his beloved that taco sauce anywhere else that dares to be green will inevitably feel his wrath: "This is NOTHING like the taco truck. Blech!"  (Yeah, we call it "the taco truck," because after all these years we still can't pronounce the name.)

So that's the deal.  Basically, come here with your meat-eater buddies, but don't bring your veggie girlfriend unless you want to hear her body make sounds like a sea lion in heat.
author: Rosie W.

description:
I've had my fair share of food on wheels...from LA's infamous Kogi truck, to the calbi tacos, and the food truck meet ups at Fort Mason... El Tonayense deserves 5 stars because it's really good minus all the fancy bells and whistles! It's a taco truck. It's not a fusion of any sort and instead offers all the basics.

5 stars for their carne asada! They make great burritos and/or tacos.  The super burrito (versus regular) comes with rice, guacamole, sour cream, beans, and hot sauce! Don't worry, the hot sauce isn't too spicy and for comparison purpose, i think hot cheetos get spicy after a while.

They also have grilled chicken, lengua, al pastor, and all that good stuff. Forget all the fake junk and questionable beef in Taco Bell's tacos because El Tonayense serves it up marinated with onions, hot sauce, and cilantro like a real taco should be.
author: Samantha L.

description: We had our office lunch catered and my carnitas burrito exceeded my expectations.  A lot of times it's hard to maintain burrito quality with mass catered lunches, but I was impressed.  The burrito included all expected ingredients, including cheese and guacamole, which most places often are stingy with.  They even brought us a MASSIVE side of guac for our chips.
author: Kristen F.

description:
My recent discovery is the steak quesadilla :) It's amazing.  I'm starting to like it more than the carne asada burrito! 

Sometimes they run out of silly things like CUPS, LIDS for cups, PLASTIC BAGS, and straws.  It really sucks especially when you're craving their pineapple drink!
author: Alicia A.

description:
One of the best taco trucks around. 
Great prices, and great selection. 
My rule is if they serve Lengua, it's legit.
author: Tim G.

description:
The worst case of food poisoning ever!!!!!!

On Wed Sept 19th I hadn't eaten anything all day and thought I would try out El Tonayense and ordered a pollo asado (chicken) burrito.  
While eating the spicy burrito I could tell I was going to get heart burn later.  Little did I know I would be up at 1:00am throwing up for hours well into the next day. This has cost me two days of work and now Sat Sep 22nd I still can't eat without feeling nauseas. 

I usually don't write reviews about food complaints but after reading other reviews I see that this is not the first case of food poisioning for this truck, nor the first with food quality and safety issues.  

Note: This truck also has multiple Yelp postings with other food safety and health related complaints.

They should probably be inspected for health issues.
author: Joan F.

description: Inconsistent. Every burrito I have is different and whoever makes it produces something different. I don't know how that's possible. Also, I always forget, but they have regular and spicy sauces/salsas. They always just decide for me what's goin in. Not super stoked, $7 for a burrito and you never know what you're gonna get. Arg. And also once I found a really long hair in my burrito. And that made me sad.
author: Alex W.

description:
So bomb. Seriously, the best. Order the tacos, they're amazing. Tiny, slightly sweet corn tortillas,  smoky, hot salsa, and whatever you want in between. 

The truck is better than the real taqueria for some reason. 

Go here. Do it. You won't regret it.
author: Amber K.

description:
I tried El Tonayense for the first time at an Earthquakes match. I ended up going with a lengua (tongue) burrito. The meat was well prepared and had good flavor/texture. The tortilla was fresh and the overall eating experience was very pleasing. It was just the right sized burrito -- nothing too hefty and filled with a good proportion of meat, rice, and beans. I could have gone for more salsa and cheese in the burrito but am not too picky so long as it tastes good, which it did. I'd consider trying El T. again but maybe not at an Earthquakes match (see below)..

There are a couple things I'm puzzled about to say the least. First, I originally asked for a torta, but the guy taking orders said they weren't making any. But the menu had tortas on there and hadn't been crossed out. Next, I asked for a beverage but was then told they weren't selling beverages...when they've got dozens of beverages sitting there. They didn't have any signs for this, which sucks if you're waiting in line for a while. Lastly, when I went to pay the $8 for my burrito, I handed the cashier a 20. He then told me they didn't have change for it. If it weren't for my friend who had two 10s, I would not have been able to afford my burrito and would have stood in line and placed my order for nothing. Where are the signs/notices?

El T, you guys need to step it up, at least at Quakes games.
author: Nick P.

description:
Great tacos! Cheap, authentic, delicious. I had three tacos al pastor for under $5. The meat was super tasty. 

Parked right next to Best Buy. Convenient as far as taco trucks parking near restrooms often goes...
author: Christian S.

description: Update:  They don't have tongue anymore. The other tacos like beef, chicken, and pork are greasy and mediocre.  Sad.
author: Kelly M.

description:
This place hits the spot.

They are:

*Open surprisingly early for a Sunday morning - I went around 10.30a.
*Fast food without the guilt.
*A mobile load of Quesadillas, Tacos, Burritos, Tortas, etc.
*Delicious
*Clean
*Inexpensive = recession-friendly
*Nice service.
*Easy parking - in the Best Buy lot ~ check out the entertainment.
*Tip Jar - says 'tip if you're sexy'...hmmmm.
author: Cathy K.

description:
Who would have thought that something from a truck prepared in a tiny space would taste *better* than something prepared in a spacious kitchen with all the space you could ever want?

I had two chicken tacos and a coke -- a filling lunch for less than $5. The chicken was tender and flavorful and hot sauce is delicious with the perfect level of heat! 

This is my new favorite lunch place in the Mission (thank you to the awesome person who gave me the lowdown on the lunch places in the area)!
author: Dani D.

description:
I've come here a couple of times now and it's time for me to give the review.

I usually come here when i have to cover a shift a work in the Mission area and I sometimes forget to bring a lunch. The only reason why I've been here is because it's really the only thing that's around for me to eat unless I want to eat out of a vending machine. 

I've had the tacos and the burritos and you should only have the tacos. The burrito I had was nasty. Chewy meat, and it was sort of cold in the center. Taco is solid but even then I've had better. 

I make sure to bring lunch for myself, but in a pinch and you could hold out until work was over then I guess i would go there.
author: Zachery H.

description:
Their taco's are a must! Carne asada taco x 3. That will fill you up for sure! Every time I stop by Best buy or go to Costco, this is a must stop. If your not hungry, just get one taco. Two-three bites and your done! These guys has been around before food trucks were even popular, that's why they have this permanent location. I'm a fan!!

-SFCheapGrub
author: Mike H.

description:
One time I ate here and it tasted like five stars.  Then three other times I ate here it was only two to three stars.  I don't know what happened but I want that magical time back.  The carne asada burrito was perfectly balanced and the sauce was amazing.  And no, I was never drunk/hungover when I ate here.

I like this place and usually just get it if I'm doing a Best Buy stop after work.
author: Erika C.

description: I have been here several times before and although the food is good, and I mean really good, this last few times have been less than edible.  My burrito was a luke-warm mess of guacamole and a bit of meat while my chips were stale like they had been left open for days in a bag from Costco.  The Horchata was a saving grace but it didn't make up for the second dinner I had to make for myself later on.  I may go back and give it yet another chance, but my faith has been taken away.
author: Kevin J.

description: Is it odd that I feel the same truck up the street at Best Buy makes a better taco?
author: David S.

description:
We arrived too late to get a Chicharron burrito at La Palma Mexicatessen, and happened upon a street fair running nearby. We were too late to get something from most of the vendors, and opted for burritos from the El Tonayense Taco Truck instead. 

He had a super carnitas burrito, and I had the pollo asada super burrito. They were good. Not amazing, not horrible - tasty but kind of anemic. He kept asking if there was any rice in mind, cause he couldn't find any in his. He also didn't care for the green sauce, though I enjoyed it.

I'll be back if it's convenient, but won't drive across town for it.
author: Karen C.

description:
Love love love these burritos.  I like the grilled chicken option.  Strangely, right after I eat one of these burritos, I don't want another one from here for at least a couple of weeks.  I think its because their special saucy sauce is really pungent and while delicious, it can be a little overwhelming (you know, it like, makes your hands smell like burrito for many hours and then you don't want to think about burritos anymore for a while).  Great to put in a rotation of more standard burritos (Metate, Cancun, El Toro, etc.) for a yummy change of pace.

However, I wish they served chips.

Also, I think its amazing that you can rent the truck for events-- we almost hired one for our wedding-- its only like, $600 for many hours of tacos.
author: Kristin P.

description: My first SF burrito was from this truck - I've had my fair share of delicious burritos in San Diego, but dang, from my first bite El Tonayense surpassed most of them. I haven't had any of their other items, but I hereby grant them 5 stars on the basis of their amazing $6.25 burritos alone.
author: An Y.

description:
All I can think of is the al-pastor taco!!!

Yum!!!
author: Terrine B.

description:
Taco truck!! This is the real deal folks. Make no mistake, not all taco trucks are created equal. This is one of the best! The burritos will send you home with a food coma and the street tacos will have your tummy screaming for more. I hate to admit this, but it's not as delicious as when I first tasted it, but it's still the top of my list as far as taco trucks go. There's nothing like going for a climb at Mission Cliffs, then rewarding yourself with some tacos!

$1.75 per street taco and ~$7 per burrito. You can't really beat that for a meal! The one thing I do wish they served was fresca. Maybe one day this favorite taco truck of mine will diversify their portfolio of offerings.
author: Angela L.

description: I didn't realize this truck was the same one outside the Best Buy on harrison! The al pastor tacos are bomb here and so is the cubano. man I'm getting hungry just thinking about it.
author: Norris T.

description:
You know, I go here often, but it's mostly out of laziness and false hope- my hope is built upon the hype that taco trucks tend to bring, and SF Mission burritos often live up to the hype- But not so here.  

I find the most disappointing thing here is the inconsistency of the meats and general make-up of the burrito.  Sure the charm of a small business is variety, but the variations of this truck suck. 

The last burrito I had was an Al Pastor, and it was quite creepy.  I think the meat is low quality and overcooked. 

Will I be back?  Sure.  But will I complain about it?  Probably. 

I'd venture to say that the truck by the Mission Clinic or Best Buy might be a slight bit better.  (Like by 1 star).
author: Melissa B.

description:
I am totally hooked on the Carnitas tacos, the salsa they use is FAN-TAS-TIC! I would love for them to have a few benches where you could sit and enjoy the tacos but the food is great and super cheap!
This is one stop you can't miss if you are in the hood....
author: Gabriel G.

description:
Updating and raising my rating.  We were jonesing burritos large last night so we ventured to the Taco Truck by Mission Cliffs.  It's only a block away from home.  We're so lucky!  But I digress.

The bump up in stars is due to the conditions under which we were served last night.  The poor guys in the truck had no lights.  Something was wrong with their electrical system and while the grill (gas powered) was working they had no light.  The dos hombres working last night were total troopers.  Our burritos were perfect despite the fact they were using their cell phones as flashlights to find their way around.  True dedication to the job seldom seen in the food service world today.  

We LOVE the Taco Truck!!
author: Russell D.

description:
I've been here a couple of times on the way home from visiting Best Buy but the food was never as good as I expected based on the high average ratings that I saw on Yelp. The other day I tried the Al Pastor burrito and finally understood why people kept mentioning it. Unlike a lot of burrito places in the city, the ingredients are fresh; you can taste the cilantros, the meat is smoky, and they use what tasted like Szechuan peppercorns in their spicy sauce. It wasn't as numbing as the Szechuan ones so it probably was another type of peppercorn but it added a nice kick to the sauce, which is also flavorful. Once everything blends together, you get a pretty good fresh-tasting burrito.

I've tried the other stuff like tongue, head and cheek, neck, carnitas, etc. but these were pretty normal. Al Pastor stands out from the rest so get it when choosing your meat.
author: Shongi H.

description:
These tacos actually made me very angry.

Yelp rarely gets it right on hardcore ethnic foods and this one certainly disappointed. The al pastor nearly activated my gag reflexes as I have never eaten it with what appeared to be ketchup-flavored PACE salsa.

Two words, one location, one GIANT mouth O: Taqueria Sinaloa, Oakland, CA, carnitas burrito with JUST RICE. TRUST.

When the meat is really good, you don't need to muck it up with rice, beans, guac or salsa.
author: Vanessa Y.

description:
This is about the Taco truck on 14th and Harrison. 
Yeah, the tacos are great, but the other things I tried aren't so special. 

First, everything except the tacos is expensive for a truck. 
Second, their vegetable Quesadilla is pretty weird and tastes like a burrito.  Because it has beans inside.  It's basically a flattened burrito.

Other than that, it's good.  For example if you just want meat tacos (they can make you a vegetarian taco, too)
I still eat the quesadilla when I have the mood for it.   

The meat in the al pastor tacos is particularly tops and famous. 

Last time tried the veggie burrito (quite some time ago) I remember it was just like the quesadilla, but more round. :))

I haven't tried other items.
author: Jordan G.

description:
Wow, major bummed out right now.
I didn't think there were ANY bad Taco Trucks in San Fran, let alone the heart of the Mission.

I just got their fish tacos (Friday only) are they are SOO spicy, I want to strangle myself.

I can handle spice, but this is UNREAL! And to think I almost said "yes" to jalapenos!! Jesus!

Also, I asked for Chips & Guac. More like Chips & Blech.
What is this? Cilantro liquid?! Horrible.
It tastes like green baby food.

Sadly, I'm probably never going back. And its literally a 30 second walk from my work.

Sucks.
author: Sara D.

description:
I came upon this taco truck at the Carnavale Festival. I wasn't too hungry so I opted the cheaper route and went for the EL Tonayense $2 tacos. I had two cabeza tacos with hot sauce. The meat is good and moist. I enjoyed it but the hot sauce isn't hot at all. I was worried at first because they had put so much on. It's more like a slurried tomato salsa than a hot sauce. Tobasco is hotter than this stuff. The "hot sauce" still adds a fair amount of liquid and tastes good.

Not the best tacos I've had but give it a shot if you see the truck.
author: Michael H.

description:
Super Burrito "al pastor", mild w/ back beans...

I was hunting for a burrito tonight. Unfortunately, they were closed. I just missed them. But the journey reminded me to post a review.

Their tacos are fresh tasting and burritos are rich in many tastes. Great mobile (truck) food. I may have to take a trip back tomorrow!
author: Michael G.

description:
mmm, mmm, mmm!  Love this taco truck!  Food is authentic, cooked fresh and is VERY flavorable!

On the corner of Harrison St in SF, I can't resist but to order my carne asado taco times 2 and a bottled Coke!  Order this with jalapenos and add hot sauce, the taco melts in your mouth!  

There's always a line here, but goes very quickly!

Got their business card and will def use them for future catering services!
author: Natalie O.

description:
Of all the Tonayense trucks around town I heard from friends that the one here at 19th and Harrison across from Mission Cliff's is the best.

The details:
 * tacos are $1.75 each
 * 3 tacos made me very full
 * burritos are $6.25
 * open until 9 PAM

I had the lengua, al pastor and carnitas tacos generously topped with salsa and served with pickled carrots and jalapeños.  All were really yummy.  Lengua was super tender but my favorite was the al pastor.
author: Jean K.

description:
The problem with evaluating food trucks is that their "addresses" as listed in sites like this keep changing. There's one listing for this place at 22nd & Harrison ("closed"), and another for 19th and Harrison. The truck that I've been to is actually at 14th and Harrison, outside the parking lot of the Best Buy. If you look at Google maps, the truck is right there in the street view photo. Is is the same as the "19th & Harrison"? Oh, I just don't know. "4" looks sorta like "9"...at least, it does if your handwriting is as awful as mine....so I'm posting under the 19th & Harrison spot. Deal with it.

Ok, enough about that. Let's talk food.

Bottom line: this stuff's good. I've had a couple of the burritos, and several of their tacos. Quick, reasonably-priced, and you leave feeling full but not slammed. They manage to season the food so that it's not the bland 'gringo Mexican' food that you find in a big chain restaurant. Good meat, good sauce, and not over-filled with cheap rice (unlike some other places). In a word: GOOD. And since the food is by definition "to go", you can grab some extra stuff for later.

Note: When you ask for it very spicy, they make it *VERY* spicy. If you're the type of person who claims they like spicy food and then immediately recoils at the first sign of that zinging sensation on the tongue (which is about 75% of people who "love spicy food"), then just get it plain.

It's actually about a mile from where I work, but it's worth the walk. 

4.1 stars.
author: Tim B.

description:
The Tacos themselves are 5 stars, I am only taking 1 star off for the service.

The tacos are small (about 4 inches in diameter), but what they lack in size they greatly make up for in flavor. I had the carne asada, but the real treat was the pork one. The sauce on that was AMAZING. I also got the Mexican bottle of Coke, which tastes different (and better) than the canned American counterpart: the bottle is a little sweeter and less carbonated, which actually complements the spice of the tacos well.

There seem to be other trucks from this company in the area, so I would check it out wherever there is one by you. It's kind of hard to eat them standing up with a drink though, so I plopped myself down on the sidewalk, having no where else to go.

I only take one star off because they gave me 5 of one taco type and one of the other and charged me $12! I didn't know the number I would be getting of anything, since the signage doesn't indicate the cost per taco nor how many come in an order. Why he picked 5 and 1 for me, I don't know that either.
author: Josh R.

description:
Oh man, oh man, on man! I am so happy I finally decided to stop for El Tonayense. I had the Torta al Pastor, spicy, with everything, and it was perfection on a bun. Perfect blend of spicy and cool. 
El Tonayense, your kiss is on my list. Love.
author: Carnley P.

description:
For years I thought the El Toyanese truck had magical teleportation powers; first it would be on the corner by Best Buy, then *poof* I'd see it near 19th. I would follow it devotedly around the city, puzzled by the varying tastiness until the one on 14th started sporting a spiffy new paint job, and I realized my favorite of the fleet (of 5!) was the plain white original.

Despite their selection of savory Mexican delights ranging from burritos to tortas, I haven't nor will ever stray from the tacos. They dish the cow out from sesos, cachete and lengua to simply carne asada, and BBQ and grill the shit out of chicken and pork goodness. Spicy, juicy and flavorful. The tacos come piled high with salsa verde, fresh onion and cilantro. The only thing that would carry my eye roll any higher would be a nice chunk of radish to accompany my $1.75 pockets of awesome.

The folks there are damn friendly. Once when eating out in the drizzle, the owner opened up a nearby restaurant, allowing us to sit inside regaling us with stories of the truck's adventures, and then cleaned up our plates afterwards as I drained the horchata in glee.

Best five buck meal to date.
author: Ligaya T.

description:
Really good tacos. the spicy salsa+ grilled chicken is good and hits the spot.  

You'll need an extra napkin or five.

And damn you guys for strategically parking right outside of mission cliffs, and temping me every time I go there and come out with a hungry stomach. jk I heart you.
author: Jennie L.

description:
As good as a classic taco truck gets!

Having just returned from Portland, where street vendors have bought up every old delivery truck and made a go at the food business, I really appreciate the Tonayense crew -- nothing flashy, just a clean, well run truck that serves great tacos and gets 100 scores by the health inspector.
author: Kurt F.

description:
My buddy David B. introduced me to this place last year. I remember coming having a completely empty stomach and full wallet. As such, it was my mission to try as many things as possible and eat as much as possible. For less than $10, I devoured 4 different kinds of tacos (carne asada, carnitas, pollo, etc.) and nearly all of a massive quesadilla. The tacos had dual warm tortillas, meat, diced onions, cilantro, and your choice of salsa. We sat in a parking lot next to where the truck was parked while we ate our food. 

If this truck was parked at Fillmore and Sacramento, I'd be broke and 20 pounds heavier. Since it isn't, it will have to be for 2 hour lunch breaks when someone can drive to the mission.
author: Jonathan G.

description:
I worked about a block from this truck for about 9 months.  I probably went about twice a week--sometimes more!   It's quite good!

Very basic stuff--tacos, quesadillas, burritos.

Sometimes spicy, sometimes not, sometimes greasy, other times REALLY greasy.  But always great!
author: Brian S.

description: Just had an amazing burrito at the LEAP Sand Castle Competition. I had a delicious chicken burrito and so did my wife. Our son are two beef tacos, that he loved.. We ordered two cokes. All for $20. Very impressed and very full! We highly recommend this truck. Superb flavor!
author: Chase L.

description: I was served a disgusting carne asada burrito from this truck awhile back. The "steak" was chewy like gum and completely inedible. Gross.
author: Scott S.

description:
[A-only review]
I don't mind the two minute walk here for the ultimate in burrito satisfaction. As far as taco trucks go, El Tonayense has gotten it down to a science. That's why you see so many of them around. 

I prefer the burritos, but the tacos are also nice and oily (but good). The meals are very juicy, although the last time I was there, I had some pretty dry pollo asado. It's okay, my gut can probably live without the animal fat, but if I'm willing to eat taco truck food, I'm probably not worried about my health.

There's not much to say. I'd gladly make small talk, but that's not why you're on your iPhone right now reading this review. You just want to know whether or not you should come here or go to some yuppy sandwich shop (ahem... Stable...). Yeah, you should come here. Your stomach will thank you. (No offense to Stable, but people love the grease.)
author: Kel S.

description: Their El Pastor tacos is amazing--only $1.75!  Order any burrito spicy or mild. Truck can be found across the street from Mission Cliffs climbing gym. Closes at 9:20pm on weekdays.  My go to place after a hard workout.
author: Wing C.

description:
I would have given 5 Stars for sure but the tacos are $0.50 more than I expected - they should be only $1, not $1.50

Other than that.... this place is the bomb. This was actually my first experience at a taco truck. I ordered 6 tacos - all lengua - and they were excellent. It's easy to mess up lengua, but these guys obviously knew what they were doing. Not too crispy, not too greasy. Just right.

Plus they let you have as many jalepenos as you want - some places make you ask for them. 

One time I got a quesadilla de queso and I almost died when I saw how much cheese they put in it. Seriously it was like a half inch of cheese all the way through.

Good eats.
author: Mike B.

description: Got the burritos once, not the best idea. Great burrito but I'm spoiled in the mission district with mexican food. By far the tacos are the best, must buy!
author: Marc M.

description:
Very fresh, very clean, very cheap. This truck is probably cleaner than any restaurants that I have ever seen. 100 on their score card from their inspection. 

I hate to say this but if it was just a bit dirtier and a little greasier this place would be the perfect taco truck. You know you need to have the aged grill or that rustic over used skillet to give you that soulful taste to the meats. It's sorta like a brand new wok/skillet/pan when you first get it. It just don't taste the same. All the ingredients are the same but there is something about the grill that just gives it that extra oomph. 

Had the beef tongue, pork, and chicken tacos. 1.75 each. There are taco trucks out there that are probably a buck each but you probably won't find one as clean and as fresh.

Yes.........I went to all of these places in one day.  Creme brulee, Phat philly, Humphry Slocombe, and now...........El Toyanese.  I am done.
author: jason g.

description: Supposedly, this is the best truck of the version of this chain of food trucks. Unfortunately, I didn't have a great experience. I ordered a carne asada super burrito and asked for it to be spicy. The meat didn't taste too fresh and the burrito was totally bland. I had a difficult time trying to finish my food because I didn't want to waste it. It will be awhile before I decide to give this truck another chance.
author: Rosie M.

description: The burritos here are the best I've had in San Francisco. Great meat and sauces (and way better than the restaurant of the same name). Go to the truck that sets up at 22nd & Harrison.
author: Eddie H.

description:
I'm from LA so my standards for mex food and specifically tacos & taco trucks are as high as they get.

I had honestly been disappointed by my other experiences with bay area tacos, however El Tonayense was the best i've had outside my home city by far. The meat was well seasoned and the tortillas were soft.

Now they need to open a truck on the eastbay side.
If your in the SF you should give this truck a try!

-eli
author: Elijah O.

description: This place is cheap fast and pretty darn tasty. I love that they have Buche and Lengua on the menu everyday!! Yea I'll recommend it but only if you buy me a taco.
author: Indy N.

description:
Oh amazing taco truck, where have you been all my life?!? 

I can't believe I just discovered this magic truck of deliciousness!  My friend Siu L. took me here this past Sunday and my taste buds went into a frenzy upon my first bite of that savory, juicy, saucy al pastor taco!  I love al pastor, and this truck really gets it!  The meat was perfect, and the tortilla was hot, there was a slice of lime, and best of all it was only $1.75!  It could've been a spicier, but it was still oh-so good! 

I also tried the carnitas taco, which was pretty good too, but if you go here, definitely get the al pastor!
author: James C.

description: I heart tacos. I mean, I really really heart tacos. That being said, I've hit up this truck when I'm low on time and en route to some other place. The tacos are reasonably priced, fresh, and generally good. Sometimes they're awesome and sometimes they're okay. The important thing is that they're always here, open, and whip up tacos when I need them.
author: Loli L.

description:
On a day to day basis, the food quality is hit-or-miss. However, El Tonayense burritos and tacos never fail to fill you up when you're on the go.

I only wish that the guys would grill the tortillas more, so they wouldn't taste like they came straight out of the bag.
author: Be N.

description:
Not very good at all.  The meat is stale tasting and lame salsa.  The burritos are fairly underweight as well and primarily of the "bean and rice" spectrum instead of the "meaty". 
If you're too lazy to wait in line at a real taqueria this might be an acceptable option for food, or if you're taste in tacos is below that of a dog who licks its own ass, then go for it.  Or if you like the novelty of buying things from trucks, in which case you're probably white, and don't live in the area.
But otherwise, if you live anywhere near here then stay away.
author: Johan E.

description: After having a bad experience at their restaurant, I reluctantly gave them a try today.  I ordered two carnitas tacos and they were awesome!  They were generous with the carnitas (slightly crispy on the edges of meat, soft and moist on the inside).  I got them spicy and it had a good kick too it, but it wasn't overly spicy.  The carnitas paired with the salsa was awesome!  I will definitely be back for more tacos.  They're an great deal at $1.75each!  I went after the usual lunch rush and there were only a few orders in front of mine.  My tacos came out rather quickly.
author: Veronica N.

description:
It was JUST alright, especially after reading all the hype. 

This review is about the truck on 22nd/Harrison...couldn't find another place to post it.

Happened to be in the area last week while making my weekly pilgrimage to the original Philz. Remembered reading about this one on Yelp and figured it was close enough to lunch to give it a shot.

I was a bit disappointed. Ordered three tacos...pastor, carnitas and lengua (my gauge when trying a taco truck). Pretty skimpy on the meat portions, and the watered-down salsa must have been made using the "pulverize" setting on the Cuisinart. Also, they seemed to be serving the white corn tortillas. Don't know if that's a regular thing, but my preference is for the standard yellow corn when it comes to taco stands. Service or lack thereof was a non-factor.

And then there's the $1.75/ea vs. the $1/ea standard that is the norm with these kind of fine eateries. The $1 tacos I get when the craving strikes at Ruddy's (see my previous review) kill these. Even Angelica's (also $1) is noticeably better. They taste better and cost 42% less. Of course, neither are in the city, and the price IS what the market will bear. 

IF these tacos were $1, my rating would go up to 3-stars which I define as "average" on a 5-star scale (as opposed to Yelp's "A-OK").

Price not being a factor, if you really like good tacos, take a drive 10 minutes south of here and check out the options. If you're gonna buy 2-3 tacos, the money you save covers your gas to get there and back!!!
author: J C.

description: Awesome!!! Reserved one of their trucks for our wedding. Had unlimited tacos off of their menu plus quesadillas and burritos! Salsa had good flavor and tasted fresh. Can't wait to check out the restaurant!
author: Claudia P. T.

description:
*             [========================]
              [[ &&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&&& ]]    
               [        EL TOYANESE TACO         ]                
              //                                                       \\
            //                                                          \\
         //___________________________\\========]]
           [[                                                          ]]                     =====]]
           [[     []======[]   []==========[]    ]]     ______              ]]
           [[     []       [      []   []            []         []    ]]     =               ]          ]]
           [[     []======[]   []_____[]____[]    ]]    [_______ ]          ]]
           [[___________________________________\\\\\\\\\\]]
                         @@@                                          @@@
                       @@@@                                      @@@@
                           @@                                              @@

Review No. Two

The "Mish" was the forbidden zone for people who lived in North Beach back when I was in high school at Galileo (on Bay Street).  One day, the Mish (Mission High School) came over and "decorated" the Gal's Court Yard with their school logo and "Mish Rules".    So our Merry Band of "Lions" returned the favor and the word was out we stay out of their hood.  After a huge "bang" of Mish and Galileans spreading their good will and the SFPD had to break up their torrid affair.

So decades later, I hear about this famous El Toyanese Taco Truck and their famous secret "green sauce".  I was riding in a Luxor Cab to another focus consumer research  (uno a uno) interview.  I spied the taco truck and told the cabbie to stop.  Food is more important than fear and safety!  I jumped out, slowly assessing the location on Harrison Street and ordered their pork taco and their pork burrito.    The senor wrapped the goods for me and I mentioned hearing about their famous green secret sauce.  He smiled quietly and poured the dark green sauce in a container for me to take home.  Ole!   The generously packed pork taco with the cilantro and the magic sauce is what everyone (even as far as LA Yelpers) raved about is outstanding.

Putting aside my childhood fears, I will be returning to El Toyanese Taco Truck and order a dozen (pork, chicken and beef) taco with their cillantro/green sauce!
author: Marian G.

description: Oh man I love me some El Tonayense!  I love the carne asada tacos with the spicy salsa and cilantro and onions - YUM!  The super burrito al pastor (aka super delicious gut bomb) is so good.  Oh my gawd I think I just drooled on myself a little thinking about it.  Yep, I need a napkin for that and a burrito fix.  Stat..
author: Kim M.

description:
I used to work at the Best Buy where this place is. Generally speaking I would always warn my co-workers "Don't eat anything there, you'll get diarrhea". 

This place is NASTY. I realize few Yelpers will agree with me, but then again half the reviews I read on yelp are idiots anyway. - "HERP DERP DEY DIDN'T WIPE MY BUTT AFTER I SPAT ON THEM!" You know the type.
author: Chris B.

description: Green chicken there is amazing! Mario and his staff are so sweet and accommodating. The best!!
author: Stacey D.

description: I've been eating at Taco Trucks before they were hip and cool... This is the real deal... Order lengua or carne asada and you won't be disappointed... Make sure to get all the fixins and order spicy!
author: Max J.

description:
One of my favorite taco trucks just fell the F*$k off.
I don't mean to be all pinche but what a let down.

First of all, what's with the $2 tacos? 

Second of all, I ordered a carne asada burrito and got al pastor. 
...um, if i was Jewish or Muslim I would have been in for a sacrelicious experience, but I'm not and it wasn't (delicious)...and WHERE IS THE CREAM AND CHEESE???? Damn you!

I've had better burritos in the airport. You guys blew it...too busy slapping each other around in the truck. 

I speak fluent taco truck and I am sure I said carne asada!

...and what happened to the al pastor? I remember a tastier more well done meat on past visits. Cook that SH!T next time before you make someone sick! It's RAW!

You need to concentrate on quality and not so much on the cheezy wrap on your truck.

I'll be back, not too soon, so if you fix it I might delete this review.
author: Charles F.

description:
Quick, friendly, and filling. Carne Asada burrito was killer. Not packed with too much rice (filler).

If you eat one one don't plan on eating the rest of the day.
author: Roger H.

description:
SO GOOD!

I am particularly fond of the one outside of Mission Cliffs. How many times have the chicken tacos ($1.75 small but packed with goodness) saved my butt in the middle of a weekday evening climb sesh? Pretty much whenever I go. 

Can't beat the price. My boyfriend says the burritos are just okay. I'm a taco girl anyway so that's just fine with me!

They offer a wide array of meat if you're into that (brain, tongue, yup) as well as a vegetarian option.
author: Claire G.

description: My favorite taco truck - love the hot sauce.
author: Katie W.

description:
Eat here if you're looking for good fast food.

I've been to two of these trucks (@ Shotwell and @ Best Buys), and both are great! Hard to beat $1.50 for a taco. The Best Buy location is nice b/c of the parking.

Surprisingly clean, and they received a 100 rating for inspection.
author: Mike L.

description:
4 tacos. 2 al pastor, 1 carnitas, 1 lengua. no cilantro. hot salsa. oh, and some horchata, please!

$8.50?!? how much is it per taco? $1.75 . . . i've been spending too much time on E14th in Oaktown (~$1.25/taco) so i had to scramble for two more bucks including some change i had to run back to my car for. at least the Tonayense truck by Best Buy has a price list!

regardless of my value-o-meter plummeting it was a tasty lunch. the carnitas and lengua were great. the carnitas had tons of flavor and were super juicy. the lengua just melted in my mouth.

the al pastor was good, but way over sauced. the hot salsa was more on the medium side, but the pickled jalepeno and carrots helped make up for it.
author: Andrew C.

description: The al pastor is the shiz. There is nothing better than marinated beef that is tender and melts in your mouth with every bite like butter. It is damn good on either the super burrito or the taco. I also like to ask for some extra peppers on the side cause I'm not a pussy. This happens to be one of my favorite food trucks. I seriously eat here or should I say stand here about 2-3 times a week! It's definitely not the cleanest food truck (the cashier happens to wrap your burrito with no gloves and is the one who handles all the money!). Since I haven't gotten sick off them yet I say its all good. At least I know the food is fresh as there is only so much food you can fit on the food truck!
author: Jonathon C.

description:
3.5 stars - wouldn't go out of my way to find one of the trucks.  

Bookmarked this place after it was reviewed on Check Please!  We were on our way to BiRite to pick up some ice cream and came upon this truck.  Hubby exclaimed "Hey, that's the truck from Check Please!".  We were not hungry but decided we can't pass up on this chance encounter.

While he parked on the red zone, I went to pick up a couple taco and horchata.  At first, I ordered a carnitas taco w/ horchata only.  While waiting, I noticed their menu of meat and saw lengua (tongue) and decided to add one of that.  Both with hot sauce - all came to $5 only($1.75/taco and $1.50 horchata).  

The carnita was a bit greasy and dry but tasty.  The lengua was very very tender and pretty tasty.  Some topping seem to be missing from the taco, perhaps not enough of the cilantro?  Not sure but it wasn't quite as satisfying as expected and we love a good taco.
author: Gloria H.

description:
One of the most difficult things about grabbing a "quick" burrito in the Mission is that the time spent to find parking never makes it quick. Enter the #1 taco truck in all of San Francisco. After easily finding a parking spot in the Best Buy lot and waiting in a 5 deep line, I never imagined eating over a garbage can could be so much fun, but after succumbing to the infamous green sauce they slather over all of their menu items I was an instant convert. The guys working in the truck are very nice and friendly and show pride in the quality of food they serve out of the tiny station. 

One of the most satisfying items on the menu is the Al Pastor burrito which is made with barbeque pork. One of the interesting aspects to the burrito is that it is long and thin and thus holds its shape better while you eat it and is less messy than a typical burrito. After you're done, if the Best Buy bathroom is too far of a hike, then jump back in your car,  squirt a little Purell on your hand and you're off to your next destination.
author: Mark Y.

description:
what i ordered... super burrito with carnitas and taco with al pastor

...food preparation was BLATANTLY UNSANITARY, the person who was handling money and taking orders was the same person rolling the burrito(s) without washing hands or donning gloves. 

without the tortilla, the fillings were so-so..... meat and rice were ok then doused with soupy sour cream and soupy guacamole. al pastor taco was good, great sauce it was cooked in.

ambiance... bad(truck in a shady area)
service... ok
cost... $
author: Gors P.

description:
I was inspired to write my review for the El Tonayense taco truck on 19th and Harrison after my crappy meal at Taqueria Cancun on Mission St.

Don't know why it's taken me so long to put in a review for El Tonayense.  What can I say, although I've only tried the tacos I am hooked.  This truck is conveniently located right outside of the Mission Cliffs climbing gym.  It makes for a great post-climb snack to hold me over before I can get home to the East Bay.

The guys that run this truck are very friendly and personable.  Although I may not look like it, I speak a good amount of Spanish (studying and having lived in Spain), so I always enjoy practicing when I can.  They always seem to welcome me speaking Spanish and in fact are very chatty.  It makes for a good time.

I highly recommend the carnitas and al pastor tacos.  Be careful for the pickled hot peppers and carrots.  They are good but are really spicy!  Don't be fooled, this one isn't really a roach coach...it actually was featured on the news a while back.  Oh, and did I mention, tacos are just $1.75!
author: Christopher W.

description:
The tacos were pretty ok.  The pollo asado was nice and juicy and the hot sauce was flavorful with just a touch of spice.  The carne asada was weird.  It didn't taste right and was dry.  There was a sweet flavor to the carne that did not compute.  meh... The pickled jalapenos were very good and the ice cold Mexican Coke out of the glass bottle was a refreshing addition to the meal.  

If I'm going to shop at Best Buy and haven't eaten yet then I may be back for a couple more pollo asado tacos and a Mexican Coke.
author: Tysen C.

description:
Sure I eat at the Michelin star restaurants, hang out at the posh new lounges in the City, and been known to take a few glasses down at those wine bars we have -- but there is nothing better than a classic Taco Truck like Tonayense.

Skip the burritos, go straight to the tacos and tortas.  Sure you know the carne asada and chicken tacos well but venture out and try the lengua and al pastor tacos these are spectacular and for the price order by the dozen!
author: G R.

description:
Removing a star, last time I had a Quesadilla from here I got the shits, if you know what I mean (why sugarcoat it?)

This taco truck rocks and is conveniently located around the corner from the Homestead. I don't dig their burritos but the chicken tacos and chicken quesadilla are super tasty. The tacos are pretty cheap and they are tiny so you will probably going to want to order a couple and definitely ask for:
- extra lime
- green sauce
Trust me on this!!! Its the green sauce that make these tacos.
I would eat a Quesadilla from here every day they are so damn good (SB and I have a debate as to whether they are better than El Farolito, this may actually result in a side by side taste test) but then I would turn into a fatty fatkins.
Also the quality of said taco may depend on who is working, I have found that the after 6pm tacos are friendliest and tastiest.
author: Catty C.

description:
I will be driven to my wedding in a roach coach.

Once dead, my carcass will hopefully be driven to whichever ravine in which I am to be dumped in a roach coach.

In the meanwhile, I will consume roach coach food with gumption. Their carnitas is some of the best in town. And come on -- huge lunch for two for $10. And for some reason, the most disagreeable and trashiests of the hipster trash stay away, maybe because their fixies can't make it up the hill*.

Also this place is apparently illegal, some sort of permitting issue. So it's even cooler! Fuckin renegade roach coach yeah!

http://www.examiner.com/x-356-SF-Education-Examiner~y2008m8d29-The-catering-truck-flap-Its-about-kids-health

*There's no hill**.
**So maybe their stupid jeans are too tight***
***Hey hey, my my: hipster bashing will never die.
author: Chris R.

description: Awesome little taco truck! I'm a fan of their tacos and the green sauce they use its mild and just right for someone who doesn't like a lot of spice. Their super burrito is very good as well. Very convenient being outside of best buy and all too. 5 stars!
author: Ashley K.

description:
Sometimes I wake up with a hangover on Sunday morning.  Maybe I shouldn't have ordered that third martini that really started the downward spiral, but there's nothing to be done about that now -- I can't un-drink those martinis (or at least it's too late to try something drastic like that).

At any rate, on these Sunday mornings with previously stated hangover, I take a brisk stroll down to this taco truck and pick up a couple of incredible, so-simple-yet-so-good spicy/savory tacos with extra jalapenos.  I make sure to get them to go but without foil so that on my way home to enjoy these little frisbees of perfection, I can walk by the crunchy raw vegans hanging outside Gratitude waiting for a table and let the heavenly scent of grilled chicken swirl in the wake of my passing.  For some reason this act of bitter menu-hating helps cure my hangover almost as much as wolfing down the tacos soon afterwards.
author: John F.

description:
Love this truck. After a hard climb half a block away at Mission Cliffs, there's nothing more gratifying than walking over to this truck and picking up four beef tacos, spicy and a bottle of Coke (made in Mexico, the only way to go, baby!)

Good price, good food. I'll cry if this truck disappears. (Don't cry for me El Tonayense! The truth is, I never left you!!!)
author: Gregg G.

description:
I wouldn't call myself a culinary expert of all foods served off a freaking truck but i have to say, i've grown very very fond of the El Tonayense taco truck over the years.  5 years ago, my then-boyfriend had to nearly ketamine-drug my ass to get me to eat off the truck but 2 weeks later, i was willing to eat it 3 times a week.  

The carne asada tacos are delish, make sure you have them put the cilantro/onion salsa on top of it.  That, coupled with a orange soda and you're all set for a better-than-sex meal (or maybe that was just better-than-sex-with-my-then-boyfriend meal).
author: Carol T.

description: I dont know what's going on here... I had it once before and it was fresh and delish..but today..rrrhrhrhrh...the tacos were dry...and my husband quesadilla...dryyyyyy.....disappointed...
author: Pikachu P.

description:
Yes, these are the best tacos I have ever eaten.  From a roach coach aka taco truck.  I encountered these lovely morsels way back in 05'.  Yummy!!  My husband and I were trekking all over the City and ended up at one of their locations on Harrison.  These tacos were so good that on a return visit my teenage son ate 8 tacos.  These tacos are so good they were even featured on Check Please Bay Area.

This is my favorite "Cheap Eats" in the City.  The meat is not dry and the salsas taste homemade like my honey makes them.

Check it out!!!
author: Karla B.

description:
4 1/2 stars for this place?! Really?!

I ordered a cabeza (head & cheek) taco and a SUPER al pastor burrito.

The taco was eh. The cabeza itself was tasty but the taco was drowned in a tasteless/watery "salsa."

Either they gave me the wrong burrito or screwed up in the process of assembling it. The meat didn't taste like al pastor and there was nothing in the burrito but pinto beans, a little rice, some sort of ground meat and the main ingredient..LOADS of neon red grease! I thought a super burrito would come with some of the following: cheese, guac, and sour cream.

I was left without satisfaction, but instead, a filmy layer of grease in my mouth.

I could easily name dozens of other taquerias/taco trucks in the bay area that are much, MUCH better than this over-rated grease pot on wheels. Some of which include, but are not limited to, El Farolito, Taqueria Cancun, and Gordos.

I give them 2 stars instead of 1 because there is a slight chance that today was a fluke and normally they are better? But, I would rather not  gamble on this place in the future, when I KNOW there many are other places that offer dependable quality food. 

Thanks, but no thanks.
author: J C.

description: I found the chicken burrito to be average at best, low quality ingredients, and a bit high priced for a truck.
author: Robert B.

description: My choice for lunch on my birthday. It's that good. You really can't beat the pollo asado tacos. Spicy. They are so so good. And now that they have the good Mexican Coke in the bottles, even better. (Just chill the Coke next time, please.) Perfectly sates that taco craving. If only I didn't live 45 miles away. But... I still make the trek. yup.
author: S M.

description: Rock climbing at Mission Cliffs + carnitas super quesadilla + horchata = perfect Wednesday afternoon.
author: Jane P.

description:
OK so I get all the good things this truck has got going for it - serious "$" as opposed "$$$$", cure-after-hangover, quick-byte-on-the-run, etc. - but people, come on! Every taqueria in the Mission has meat far superior - carne asada taco I just had tasted like total crap, pieces of meat had to be spit out, not being chewable at all. Yuck.

Then there is this issue of the entire block littered by paper plates, blown in circles in the wind in front of PG&E wall and the gray UCSF building on 19th and Harrison... but even regardless. Double yuck.
author: Sasha M.

description: I needed to grab quick burritos for my kids and this place is right around the corner. I ordered a grilled chicken burrito and 2 bean and rice only burritos and was shocked that is was $18.75. I was expecting the meatless burritos to be huge for that amount, but they were really, really tiny. There are so many other great options that are a much better value around here. My mistake. I will walk a couple more blocks next time.
author: Kerry C.

description: The carne asada burrito SUCKS!  Everything in it is dry including the hot sauce.  How do you make dry hot sauce?  Ask this truck.  They want to go on the Great Food Truck Race?  HAHHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAAHHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA.  Its probably my fault for ordering a burrito at a taco truck.  Someone needs to open a burrito truck.
author: Fatty A.

description:
Ok, I am a big fan of taco trucks... use them all the time...

So, they are *usually* $1 a taco -- lot's of them...

So great shock to see $1.75!!! (75% more??) for a taco of the same size/quality.

Does SF charge 75% more on that street v. near the court house or san bruno?  Probably.

Anyway... 

But here is the catch... if you look and speak spanish you get to go to the front of the line!  WTF??  Happened 4x during my 'lunch'...  YOu could jump the line, order in spanish and they would take your order and put it out first!!!  Yes, I speak spanish, but I would never jump the line on the non-speakers.... strange and not cool.

So, bad line management (critical for a truck) and too expensive compared to others brings this to two stars... sorry.
author: Max L.

description:
These are probably some of the most delicious tacos I've ever had and 1) they come from a truck and 2) it is conveniently located next to my apartment.

To think I used to spend double the price for sub-par tacos.
author: Bryan H.

description:
Grilled chicken quesadilla.  Every time.  I don't know what they do to that damned chicken to make it so good, but I've never had better.  I also like to get a Jarritos Mexican soda to go with it. Tamarindo and pina are my faves.   Spicy food and a sweet drink are the best combination.

I'll take that carefully wrapped greasy little bundle of love and the soda back back to the bar with me for slow, careful eating.  I get a pint glass of ice and shot of vodka to go with the soda, then I unwrap the quesadilla and chow down. So good!
author: Miss Information X.

description: Parking a taco truck outside a tech event should be a given. It is the perfect food while drinking.  I love the spicy chicken tacos.  I love loading them with sour cream and guacamole.   We are so lucky to have the variety of Mexican  food we have in San Francisco.
author: Infodiva B.

description: It's the best carne asada quesadilla you can grab on the go!  Hot cheese surrounding beef chucks swimming in guacamole and salsa.  Grab one  along your way to the Sunday Best Buy sales!
author: MTBer I.

description: This taco truck is the business! Definitely quick, cheap and a heaven scent after bouldering all day.
author: Edrian D.

description: We just had the truck for a wedding weekend dinner house party. Brilliant. Everyone loved it. Under $700 for 100 people! Catering, suck it!
author: S M.

description: Are you serious? Second worst burrito of my life. I don't even want to talk about the worst, but this one was horrible. The "carne asada" is ground beef with a powder taco flavor packet that you buy at the grocery store. And they put some kind of extra grease in it that tastes like something from an Italian restaurant. I don't have very high standards for food but they should be ashamed that they call that mexican food.
author: Alex M.

description: The only reason to go to Best Buy.  Great salsa, fresh greens, and damn tasty meat given that it was cooked in the back of a truck.  I normally go for the taco's rather than the burrito's.
author: Dean C.

description: I've been going to the El Tonayense truck at Best Buy for years and i love the food. But Sunday my wife and I both got food poisoning from the sour cream on our burritos, which evidently was not cold enough. Two days of real unpleasantness. My 2-year-old thankfully did not eat the half burrito we gave him. The response from the Benicio the manager was less than reassuring. He assured me everyone was well-trained, though acknowledged that there were some new people working on the truck, and offered a pretty weak apology. I love the food, I know the inspections are good, but just so you know, they are lacking some rudimentary food handling skills.
author: Wes C.

description:
Best burrito I've had in the city, hands down.  I usually go with he marinated pork spicy burrito, it is not humongous, but has very rich flavor.  Though their tacos are always a good choice as well.

I crave this burrito when I haven't had it a while.
author: Isabella H.

description: I wouldn't even order tacos anywhere else, it would be like cheating. Super burritos excellent, no beans of course and while we are on the subject why would people put beans in a burrito?
author: Seamus M.

description: I've been here once before and I remember thinking the tacos were great.  But, I just had the carnitas today and it was extremely dry.  I had to keep dousing it with lime to give it a little moisture but I've had better carnitas tacos (La Taqueria!).  My husband enjoyed the carne asada taco and I'm sure that's what I had previously.  Perhaps it was an off day?  In any case, the carnitas tacos weren't anything to write home about.
author: Abby N.

description: Tortas are the new tacos, at least at this addition to the El Tonayense empire. While I can't speak to the taco quality at this location (had at another location and they were awesome: http://www.yelp.com/biz/el-tonayense-taco-truck-san-francisco-6#hrid:_wpwiW82UODY_8LADcGKvw), I can speak to the torta. Mix of chicken, black beans, lettuce and salsa between Bolillos bread goodness was stellar. Good enough to pass up whatever taco craving you might be satisfying. You want a torta, you just don't know it yet.
author: Jason B.

description: The whole fleet of el tonayense trucks are excellent, but I am particularly attached to this truck. The meats are clearly the highlight, but even the veggie burritos have just the right balance of tasty beans, rice and delicious salsa. The real star here though is the al pastor. I haven't had al pastor as good as theirs anywhere else. I have been coming here for about 7 years now and it remains my favorite mexican food in the city.
author: Peter M.

description: I used El Tonayense for a 50th Birthday / Halloween party and they were terrific!  I hired them for three hours and the guests were in heaven!  Yummy tacos, burritos and quesadillas!  Perfect situation - no fuss or muss, absolutely lovely employees and Vinicio in the catering department was was wonderful and gets back to you right away!  I can't wait for my next soirée!
author: M M.

description: This taco trucks is really nothing special. their food is super greasy and don't taste good at all. The only reason i gave it two stars is because it cheap.
author: John B.

description:
most Saturdays at 12:30p, you'll find me and my oldest daughter having tacos from this truck after skating in the morning.

cheap, consistently delicious, and good folks running it. 

always love seeing the '100' scorecard from the SF dept of health too. Not that I had any question, but always kind of a bonus.

Like I said, just about every Saturday. Totally bankable for a good, fast, cheap feed.
author: pedro w.

description:
u parked ur truck right against the best buy parking lot, u clever SOB...

gave the dude $4.50.

downed my grilled ck, carne asada, and 7-up.  *yummy*

my fingers still smelled limey and beefy as i checked out lcds and plasmas, a wonderful experience, sugoooooooi!!!
author: Ethan L.

description: DON'T GET THE TORTA TO GO!!!! i went with a coworker of mine and thought the torta would be a good idea and by was i wrong. when i got back to my office, the carne asada was almost missing from the actual torta and it looked my like 5 year old cousin had prepared it!!!! i guess i should only get the tacos??? BTW, if you want a delicious torta go to taqueria cancun on mission and valencia, they are out of this world!!!
author: jason xavier c.

description: It's OK. I put so much lime juice and hot sauce and pickled peppers on my tacos I can't taste anything anyway. Nothing beats eating on the street, except well, drinking on the street. They don't serve beer. Boo.
author: Dave T.

description: your regular quality taco truck in sf. it's a bit more expensive than angelica's or rico tacos, but there are plenty more options. overall, there are less ingredients than the other taco trucks (i.e. no radishes, very little cilantro, maybe 5 pieces of chopped onions). i had the al pastor taco today, and at $1.75, it was flavorful, tender, and packed a good punch because i ordered spicy, but i would much rather just head out to tacqueria vallarta for a $1.50 taco that's more legit (less meat options though) and has all-you-can-pile-on condiments.
author: Danny C.

description: If I'm even close to this truck, I'm stopping by for a couple of tacos. Doesn't matter if I just had lunch. They are THAT good. That's all that i have to say...
author: Sergei A.

description: My former coworker brought me to this taco truck a year ago and I have made a point to come back at least once a month. The pollo asado burrito is awesome, my stomach is starting to rumble just thinking about it.
author: Tony S.

description: It's a neighborhood secret so don't tell anyone I told you but this and the sister truck at 22th & Harrison are the best Taquerias  in the mission.
author: Manny F.

description: Best taco trucks in the city. Best prices and damn those are some good ass tacos. Love that green sauce. Yummy................Also they always have fresh chips.
author: Erin A.

description: Tried the regular burrito and the super burrito finally. The regular burrito is damn tasty! We had a grilled chicken one and it had this awesome green chile sauce. The super burrito is a little overkill especially when you order a pork based one. It just feels like way too much grease in one place, but don't get me wrong it was good. You just feel a little dirty afterward.
author: Alvaro H.

description: Good tasting burritos but could be a little bigger. Decent prices & good drinks. Never tried the tacos.
author: Craig G.

description: The Carne Asada tacos are AMAZING and very inexpensive!!!  It is always GOOD, haven't been disappointed yet!!!!
author: Susie S.

description: Just hired these cats for my 40th b-day party... wow!  all my friends and fam were totally impressed with their great tasting food and service with a smile.  Even the gringos that where shy about eating off a taco truck said they would love to throw a party and hire these guys.  AWESOME!
author: rudy G.

description: Yes! - I used to get a Citycarshare and go here for some tacos!  I miss the taco truck!
author: erik w.

description: I don't know what's in the green sauce but it's DELICIOUS!!!  This was my first visit and I will be returning frequently!
author: Zach F.

description: There are two taco trucks I am reviewing, the one at the intersection of 14th and Harrison, and the one at Harrison and Mistral Ave (between 19th and 20th).  I frequent both and they are both the same (same food, same company, hell they even live on the same street).  These trucks park in the same exact locations every day.  I asked one of the dudes working the truck the meaning of the name, and he said Toyanese is the name of a town in Mexico.  The only thing I ever eat there are the tacos carne asada, muy picante.  Yummm.  I also drink their "Mexican" Cokes (bottle, nutrician label stuck on, and made with cane sugar.)  If I were to subtract a star, it would be because their drinks are often not cold enough.  Luke warm Coke sucks.  In any event, their tacos are delish.
author: M. J.

description:
always liked it...but today I got served by some diff. dude....
they didn't grill my tortilla and the meat seemed not as flavourful...
I don't wanna sound like that old man who's cranky about his regular place of drink or eating due to some codependent comfort, but I guess I was disapointed...I will try again, maybe it was a fluke....
author: Alex W.

description: Best Al Pastor Burrito. Ever. I dream about it...Take it out though, the establishment is cold and smells like dirty mop.
author: Jackie J.

description:
best place that has good tacos, burritos and tortas all under the same (small) roof inside the bay area and outside of the oakland taco trucks on international blvd.

the test of a truely delicious burrito is the regular burrito test. if you cant eat the burrito regular then the burrito super is just a cover-up for the bad taste. crap ala mode is still crap, amirite?

and if they dont got tripas tacos then f them.
author: christopher a.

description: This is probably my favorite of the El Tonayense Taco truck empire.  It has the best location, because you can post up and eat your food in the sun.  It's on a fairly quiet streach of Harrison.  The tacos are great, cheap, fresh, and muy authentico.  I have not tried anything else yet, but I guess they have quesdillas and burritos too.  Does it get any better?
author: Ezra Y.

description: This has become on of my favorite places to bring visitors to when they come to SF. The food is always fresh and tasty - the variety of tacos is perfect. I had the tripe, al pastor and carnitas yesterday...still can't decide which I like most.
author: Austin W.

description:
unholy hell, this is my all time favorite taco truck...on either side of the bridge that is.
the guys that work the truck are awesomely nice and always hook it up. from the asada to the pastor and everything in between it's all good. throw in a jaritos and it makes for some good eats. 
one of my typical orders would be;
carne asada burrito, no beans with salsa verde and extra cilantro and onions.....try it, it rulez
author: Ax L.

description: This truck, along with its siblings outside of BestBuy on Harrison and the Mission Health Center at 16th and Shotwell, are the BEST taquerias IMHO.  The flavors are far better than any of the sit-down taquerias in the city, with the exception, perhaps, of La Taqueria on Mission St.  Not only are their burritos the tastiest, they are the cheapest, so what better combo can you get?  I only wish they stayed out later in the evening.  Oh, and the health department scores listed have always been 100% for these trucks.
author: Scott L.

description: Great cheap quick taco el Pastor and grilled chicken are best
author: jordan n.

description: MSG aside, this truck has some good tasting tacos! Bring your own plates because the paper ones they give you fall apart.
author: Da H.

description: We hired the truck for a private event on Sunday.  They fed about 400 folks and everyone raved about the food and the great attitude of the guys in the truck.  I had, for the first time, a cabeza and a lengua taco and they were both perfect!  If I lived closer, I would never enter a conventional mexican restaurant again!
author: Jim S.

description: El Toyanese is so delicious!  I love the taco's carnitas with red sauce, the tortas, everything I've ever ordered has always been really tasty.  One more place to help make me fat!
author: Amber R.

description: 3 stars for being clean and having quality foods.  deductions for not having a balance between spicy and bland flavors.
author: Timothy S.

description: nothing like two carne asada tacos with hot sauce, pickled carrots and jalapenos right before a climbing session at mission cliffs.  cheap too.
author: Robert S.

description: Had great expectations because of the good reviews, so maybe I had an off day, but I've never had a saltier burrito.
author: Camille H.

description: Probably the best taco truck tacos available.  Yum yum.  My one question though, is where does the staff go the bathroom when they're in those trucks all day?
author: Customer X.

description: The Vegetarian tacos here are just so great, I daren't asking them what goes in the beans!  Hot sauce and plenty of jalepenos.  My mouth is watering just thinking about them!
author: Nina D.

description: really good veggie burritos - they actually have vegetables in them! and they're cheap - $5.
author: Michael K.
